pageProps.contentHtml:
Weierstrass factorization theorem

Let f ⁣:C→C\func{f}{\C}{\C}f:C→C be a non-constant holomorphic function such that every zero of fff has even multiplicity.

Show that fff has a holomorphic square root, i.e., there exists a holomorphic function g ⁣:C→C\func{g}{\C}{\C}g:C→C such that f(z)=g(z)2f\p{z} = g\p{z}^2f(z)=g(z)2 for all z∈Cz \in \Cz∈C.
Solution.

Let A={an}nA = \set{a_n}_nA={an​}n​ denote the distinct zeroes of fff and let 2mn2m_n2mn​ be the multiplicity of ana_nan​, where mn∈Nm_n \in \Nmn​∈N. Indeed, because fff is non-constant, the zeroes of fff must be isolated, so each compact B(0,N)‾\cl{B\p{0, N}}B(0,N)​ can contain only finitely many ana_nan​, or else they accumulate by subsequential compactness. Thus,

A=⋃N=1∞B(0,N)‾∩A,A = \bigcup_{N=1}^\infty \cl{B\p{0, N}} \cap A,A=N=1⋃∞​B(0,N)​∩A,

i.e., it is a countable union of finite sets, so it is at most countable.

If ∣A∣=N\abs{A} = N∣A∣=N is finite, then by the factor theorem,

f(z)=b(z)∏n=1N(z−an)2mn,f\p{z} = b\p{z}\prod_{n=1}^N \p{z - a_n}^{2m_n},f(z)=b(z)n=1∏N​(z−an​)2mn​,

where bbb vanishes nowhere. If AAA is infinite, then because AAA cannot have infinitely many roots on any B(0,N)‾\cl{B\p{0, N}}B(0,N)​, it follows that lim⁡n→∞∣an∣=∞\lim_{n\to\infty} \abs{a_n} = \inftylimn→∞​∣an​∣=∞. Hence, we may apply the Weierstrass theorem, which gives existence of an entire function p(z)p\p{z}p(z) such that ppp has roots AAA, but ana_nan​ has multiplicity mnm_nmn​ instead. Moreover, b=fp2b = \frac{f}{p^2}b=p2f​ vanishes nowhere, so we have the factorization

f(z)=b(z)p2(z).f\p{z} = b\p{z}p^2\p{z}.f(z)=b(z)p2(z).

In both cases, we may write f(z)=b(z)p2(z)f\p{z} = b\p{z}p^2\p{z}f(z)=b(z)p2(z), where bbb vanishes nowhere, ppp has the same roots as fff but with half the multiplicity, and both b,pb, pb,p are entire.

Since bbb vanishes nowhere, bbb has a logarithm, i.e., there exists an entire function ccc satisfying b=ecb = e^cb=ec. Thus, if we set

g(z)=e12c(z)p(z),g\p{z} = e^{\frac{1}{2}c\p{z}} p\p{z},g(z)=e21​c(z)p(z),

then ggg is a composition and product of entire functions, hence entire itself. Moreover,

g2=ecp2=bp2=f,g^2 = e^cp^2 = bp^2 = f,g2=ecp2=bp2=f,

which completes the proof.
